Organization: The Prison Law Office and the ACLU National Prison Project
Organizing Effort: Emergency motion in federal court in Phoenix
Response (if yes or partially): ADC will lift a four-dollar charge for requesting health care and will temporarily lift the charge for soap
Additional Information: The motion asks the judge to order the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADC) to consult with a correctional health care expert to develop a plan to prevent, manage, and treat any COVID-19 outbreaks in the state’s 10 prisons.

Response (if yes or partially): 600 inmates released between 3/16/2020 and 4/9/2020
Additional Information: A coalition of civil rights organizations and attorneys signed on to a petition making demands for Santa Rita Jail in Age of Coronavirus Pandemic to lower arrest rates, decarcerate, take steps to make jail safer, and invest in health-affirming resources, such as robust health care, affordable housing, living wages, quality schools, environmental justice, and adequate transportation.
Car Rally to tell DA O'Malley and Sheriff Ahern to shut down Santa Rita Jail and release everybody incarcerated there.

Organization: "Health Care Professionals" (petition created by Mark-Anthony Clayton-Johnson of Dignity and Power Now)
Response (if yes or partially): 1,700 inmates released as of 3/23/2020
Additional Information: Petition calling on The Los Angeles Department of Health Services, Correctional Health Services, and the Local Health Officer to immediately release people in LA County jails

Response (if yes or partially): 1,700 inmates released as of 3/23/2020
Additional Information: Petition to demand Los Angeles County officials take immediate and decisive steps now to save lives in LA County Jails

Organization: California Coalition for Women Prisoners; Young Women's Freedom Center; Sister Warriors Freedom Coalition
Target Facility (if applicable): Central California Women's Facility & California Institute for Women
Response (if yes or partially): California will release 3,500 inmates serving sentences for nonviolent offenses by June
Additional Information: Participants called the Federal Medical Receiver and CDCR on behalf of people incarcerated at CCWF & CIW women’s prisons. Demanded better sanitation in prisons and the release of all elderly and medically high-risk people. Additional demands: immediate end to staff movement between prisons; that the CDCR must ensure that incarcerated people & the public have rapid access to information as pandemic conditions continue to change, and must ensure continued access to medication & all healthcare services, telephone, JPay, and mail. During a lockdown, extend WiFi access and provide personal tablets & cellphones to all people.

Response (if yes or partially): Correctional deputies released 17 inmates, the sheriff's office delivered cleaning supplies throughout the jail, and staff started handing out two bars of soap a week to each inmate and set up more than 18 hand sanitizing stations as well as two hand cleaning stations.
Additional Information: For three days, 63 inmates of F-wing were on strike over insufficient cleaning supplies, also demanding that some low-level offenders to be released, said Cmdr. John Thornburg with the Monterey County Sheriff's Office. Correctional deputies released 17 inmates meeting the criteria, and the sheriff's office also delivered cleaning supplies throughout the jail, including F-Wing.

Organization: Riverside "All of Us or None" and Starting Over, Inc
Response (if yes or partially): Sheriff Chad Bianco says he does not plan to allow early releases and that Riverside county inmates "receive excellent treatment and have greater access to medical care and more readily than most of you who are not in jail."
Additional Information: Car rally to demand the immediate release of our people incarcerated in Riverside County jails taking place in downtown Riverside during the Board of Supervisors meeting on April 21st. Attendees social distanced by staying in their cars and protesting the County’s lack of action by honking horns, making noise from their cars, waving signs, and driving the route encircling our elected officials. The rally’s route passed by the Board of Supervisors meeting, Riverside County Sheriff’s Department, and Robert Presley Detention Center, so both county officials and people behind bars will hear their demands that Sheriff Bianco #ReleaseRiverside.
column16: https://twitter.com/nolasco909/status/1250496696355745792?s=21; https://patch.com/california/murrieta/rivco-sheriff-early-inmate-release-amid-coronavirus-reckless; "If you don't want to contract this virus while you are in custody, don't break the law," Bianco said at a April 2 press conference. (source: https://www.desertsun.com/story/news/crime_courts/2020/04/16/judge-says-riverside-county-sheriffs-department-fails-amid-coronavirus-pandemic/5141460002/)

Additional Information: Asking members of the public to join their #letthemgo photo campaign by taking a photo addressed to Gavin Newsom and posting on social media with the tag #letthemgo calling on him to release all vulnerable populations from inside California prisons

Organization: Dignity and Power Now, CURB: Californians United for a Responsible Budget, and Justice LA
Additional Information: In response to the formation of the California Senate's new Budget Subcommittee on COVID-19, organizations are calling on Californians to submit public comments demanding a decarceration budget (calling on the State to do its part and help fund jail and prison decarceration efforts) in anticipation of the subcommittee's first hearing this Thursday April 16th at 2pm.

Organization: ICE detainees at the Stewart Detention Center in Lumpkin, GA
Additional Information: About 350 prisoners in Stewart Detention Center participated in a hunger strike to raise awareness that they are inhumanely caged in an ICE facility while coronavirus spreads in jails, prisons and ICE detention facilities across the country.

Organization: Inmates at Cook County Jail; Circles & Cyphers
Response (if yes or partially): On 4/27/2020, a federal judge issued a preliminary injunction that mandates additional testing and social distancing measures as well as greater efforts to clean and sanitize the jail.
Additional Information: Hunger Strike to protest health measures in Cook County Jail and demand mass release

Organization: Chicago Community Bond Fund, Moms United Against Violence and Incarceration, & more
Response (if yes or partially): The Cook County Jail population has been reduced from over 5,600 detainees in mid-March to a little over 4,100 detainees by the end of April
Additional Information: Demanding mass release

Response (if yes or partially): Cook County has been conducting expedited hearings since late March to allow a judge to determine if release is appropriate; at least 20 releases have been granted
Additional Information: Demanding mass release

Response (if yes or partially): The Cook County Jail population has been reduced from over 5,600 detainees in mid-March to a little over 4,100 detainees by the end of April
Additional Information: CCBF held a "socially distanced" vigil with community members outside the jail

Response (if yes or partially): The Cook County Jail population has been reduced from over 5,600 detainees in mid-March to a little over 4,100 detainees by the end of April
Additional Information: CCBF organized a petition for members of the public to sign onto their list of demands for government officials

Organization: Moms United Against Violence and Incarceration
Response (if yes or partially): The Cook County Jail population has been reduced from over 5,600 detainees in mid-March to a little over 4,100 detainees by the end of April
Additional Information: Demanding mass release

Organizing Effort: Focusing on people experiencing homelessness who have to register weekly in person at police, which involves being packed in bullpen for hours, where people are sick.
Additional Information: Campaign is asking the Chicago mayor's office and Governor's office to suspend in person registration. Also asking them to suspend housing banishment laws so that people experiencing homelessness can stay in homes with families , friends, or relatives. Asking offices of states attorneys to suspend Failure to Register prosecutions and meet with advocates to discuss procedures for future prosecutions.

Response (if yes or partially): The Cook County Jail population has been reduced from over 5,600 detainees in mid-March to a little over 4,100 detainees by the end of April
Additional Information: CCBF organized a call-in campaign urging the sheriff's office and the state attorney's office to take action in support of the demands in its open letter to government officials

Organization: Black Lives Matter Chicago & Free the People Coalition
Response (if yes or partially): In order to stop the spread of COVID-19 in Illinois prisons, Gov. Pritzker has granted clemency to more than 1,000 prisoners and the Cook County Jail population has been reduced from over 5,600 detainees in mid-March to a little over 4,100 detainees by the end of April

Organizing Effort: Week of Action to Decarcerate (including car rally, phone zap, petition)
Response (if yes or partially): In order to stop the spread of COVID-19 in Illinois prisons, Gov. Pritzker has granted clemency to more than 1,000 prisoners
Additional Information: Week of actions including coordinated social media actions, call ins, and a driving caravan to put pressure on public officials to do a number of things intended to protect the health and safety of incarcerated people, including population reductions.

Organizing Effort: Week of Action calling for release of people in MA jails and prisons
Response (if yes or partially): State prisons and county jails in Massachusetts released 367 prisoners after this month's state Supreme Judicial Court ruling on reducing incarceration because of the coronavirus.
Additional Information: Campaign is asking people to to make calls, emails, and post on social media every day this week, with different stakeholders targetted each day, to demand that they release as many people as possible as soon as possible

Organization: ICE Detainees at Baldwin’s North Lake Correctional Facility
Additional Information: Hunger Strike in protest of conditions that are allegedly so unsafe that some have been put in prolonged solitary confinement, demanding better food and living conditions.

Community members called the Director of the Michigan Department of Corrections regarding the 40 suspected cases of COVID-19 in the Macomb Correctional Facility to demand various health related services for people incarcerated there, as well as the release of all chronically ill and elderly people in Macomb

Wayne County Defenders created a google form where defenders could coordinate their efforts can begin to get emergency motions drafted and filed for bonds to be reduced to personal bonds for defendants.
Template and guidance on calling your lcoal jail or prison to request free phone calls during COVID-19 pandemic

Organization: 12 US Senators: Sanders, Klobuchar, Harris, Markey, Durbin, Bennet, Brown, Coons, Blumenthal, Warren, Duckworth, Wyden
Organizing Effort: Letter written to the Bureau of Prisons
Additional Information: Requests that the BOP waive fees associated with phone calls for incarcerated people and allow for unsupervised phone calls or video conferencing and emails with legal counsel for the duration of BOP's suspension of in-person visits at federal prisons

Organizing Effort: Prisoner Support Guide for the Coronavirus Crisis
Additional Information: An online educational resource available to other organizers including a sign up sheet to create a national resource to provide localized support for prisoners and their loved ones

Organizing Effort: Call for comprehensive policy response from the Department of Juvenile Justice
Additional Information: Calls for no new admissions to juvenile detention, release of all except those who present a substantial safety risk, creation of transitional plans ensuring that all youth have safe and adequete places to live, among other policy measures.

Organization: The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights
Additional Information: Petitions in support of letters letters to the National Governors Association, U.S. Conference of Mayors, and the National Sheriff’s Association urging them to use their authority to  decarcerate prisons and jails.
Zoom Rally to Free Prisoners from Rikers Island to Palestine: a webinar on Palestinian Prisoners Day in international solidarity with incarcerated people
Encouraging people to call their local ICE field office to demand they utilize all options to release all people in their custody and help stop the spread of COVID-19.

Organizing Effort: Demand for ICE to Free All People in immigrant jails and stop raids
Additional Information: DWN's members across the national are working locally to demand release of people in immigrant prisons by pressuring Field ICE Offices, Members of Congress, Governors, Mayors, City Councils, Board of Supervisors, Sherieff Departments, Health Departments and other secondary targets
column16: Follow DWN Facebook for calls to action from across the country: https://www.facebook.com/DetentionWatchNetwork/?epa=SEARCH_BOX

Organization: Immigrants detained by ICE in Essex County, Bergen County, Elizabeth, and Hudson County Correctional Facilities
Target Facility (if applicable): Essex County, Bergen County, Elizabeth, and Hudson County Correctional Facilities
Response (if yes or partially): 10 medically compromised ICE Detainees were ordered to be released from Bergen, Hudson, and Essex County Jails by a federal judge
Additional Information: Demanding immediate release; access to soap and toilet paper

Two dorms of 45 inmates at Rikers refused to leave their dorms for work duties or for meals in protest against the lack of personal protective equipment and cleaning supplies provided to them, the crowded living conditions, and the arbitrary disconnection of their phones on the morning of Sunday, March 22, 2020

Call to action for people to call Mayor De Blasio regarding a lockdown at MDC Manhattan to demand that they provide testing, proper sanitation, and access to phones/communication; also requesting general release

Organization: Parole Preparation Project, WORTH Rises, Vocal New York, RAPP, Citizen Action, Color of Change
Response (if yes or partially): In March, Cuomo's administration ordered the release of up to 1,100 people who were held on technical parole violations, and on 4/14/2020 Cuomo's top aide Melissa DeRosa said the state would begin freeing those who are aging and nearing their release date
Additional Information: Petition demanding that Gov. Cuomo use his clemency power to grant releases; put an end to forced labor in prisons & institute a living wage for incarcerated workers; stop rollbacks on bail reform and keep jail populations low

Organization: Parole Preparation Project and the Release Aging People in Prison Campaign
Additional Information: Campaign for mass clemencies, parole board releases and other grants of release. Also focused on conditions.

Organization: New Yorkers United for Justice; Release Aging People in Prison Campaign
Organizing Effort: Protests outside of Gov. Cuomo's home
Response (if yes or partially): In March, Cuomo's administration ordered the release of up to 1,100 people who were held on technical parole violations, and on 4/14/2020 Cuomo's top aide Melissa DeRosa said the state would begin freeing those who are aging and nearing their release date
Additional Information: Demanding that Gov. Cuomo grant clemency to all New Yorkers; safely and immediately release vulnerable citizens who are incarcerated
Petition demanding the immediate removal of costs to telecommunications to those incarcerated in NYS and beyond during the COVID-19 crisis
North Carolina prisoners seek to deliver a formal grievance to U.S. Attorney William Barr and other entities within the U.S. Department of Justice.
column16: Organized by Randy Watterson and Joseph “Shine White” Stewart with the support of Durham ABC and Blue Ridge ABC

Organization: People incarcerated at Franklin County Jail
Response (if yes or partially): Some greviances filed were addressed, including prison staff now wearing gloves and masks when distributing food trays.
Additional Information: Family members and friends of inmates incarcerated at the Franklin County Jail say prisoners are engaged in a hunger strike to protest what they say is a lack of sanitary items to keep themselves protected from a potential coronavirus infection.

Organization: Amistad Law Project & ACLU of Pennsylvania
Response (if yes or partially): "[Parole Board] said it’s been working to reduce the overall population by “maximizing” releases when possible. New inmates also will be held at SCI-Retreat in Luzerne County for 14 days before entering the rest of the system"
Additional Information: Community members called Governor Wolf (Pennsylvania Governor) demanding the release of vulnerable people to prevent them from dying in prison as a result of COVID19.
Several ICE detainees at York County Prison in York, Pa., went on a hunger strike in protest of what they say are insufficient precautions around the coronavirus pandemic.

Organization: ICE Detainees, with support of RAICES (Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Services)
Organizing Effort: Hunger Strike and Protests in coordination with lawsuits and campaigns demanding their immediate release
Additional Information: About 60 ICE Detainees protested at the South Texas Detention Complex in Pearsall, where some detainees have also been engaging in hunger strikes. ICE guards used pepper spray to quell the protest and placed the protestors in restricted housing and gave them disciplinary charges. About 100 detainees at the Farmville center in Texas joined in a hunger strike at the end of March that advocates say was cut short when detention center officials locked two organizers of the demonstration in solitary confinement.
Calls to support the Petition for Extraordinary Relief filed to Utah Supreme Court on April 1 to release as many inmates from the Salt Lake County Jail as quickly as possible.

Organization: Immigrant women detained by ICE in Tacoma, WA
Additional Information: Over 60 immigrant women imprisoned at Northwest Detention Center in Tacoma, Washington, went on hunger strike demanding the immediate release of vulnerable people, humanitarian visas to detainees, and a moratorium on deportations and transfers.

Organization: People incarcerated at Monroe Correctional Complex
Additional Information: Inmates at the Monroe Correctional Complex held a demonstration on Wednesday night (4/8) after six inmates tested positive at the prison. Officers fired nonlethal rounds and used pepper spray to break up a demonstration of more than 100 inmates.

Organizing Effort: Information gathering of COVID19 procedures of Wyoming Detention centers and law enforcement agencies
Additional Information: Currently in process of gathering COVID19 policies and procedures from all detention facilities in state of Wyoming, including prisons, and law enforcement agencies. Advocacy efforts depending on findings of information gathering to follow.
